Article.Abstract: DNA immunization offers a novel means to induce cellular immunity in a population with a heterogeneous genetic background. An immunorecessive cytotoxic T-lymphocyte (CTL) epitope in influenza virus nucleoprotein (NP), residues 218 to 226, was identified when mice were immunized with a plasmid DNA encoding a full-length mutant NP in which the anchor residues for the immunodominant NP147-155 epitope were altered. Mice immunized with wild-type or mutant NP DNA were protected from lethal cross-strain virus challenge, and the protection could be adoptively transferred by immune splenocytes, indicating the role of cell-mediated immunity in the protection. DNA immunization is capable of eliciting protective cellular immunity against both immunodominant and immunorecessive CTL epitopes in the hierarchy seen with virus infection.
Article.ArticleTitle: Protective cellular immunity: cytotoxic T-lymphocyte responses against dominant and recessive epitopes of influenza virus nucleoprotein induced by DNA immunization.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Virus and Cell Biology, Merck Research Laboratories, West Point, Pennsylvania 19486, USA.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Epitope NP 110-119 was defined by scanning full length NP for consensus H-2Kd binding motifs and differs from the natural influenza A/PR/8/34 NP sequence by two substitutions (E114G, E115G).

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized by vaccination using plasmid DNA encoding the full length (or mutated version) nucleoprotein of Influenza A/PR/8/34(H1N1). CTLs from immuized mice were restimulated by culture with syngeneic splenocytes infected with Influenza A/PR/8/34 in the presence of IL-2.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL from mice immunized with a plasmid vaccine specific for full-length Influenza A nucleoprotein (NP DNA), or a version of the nucleoprotein mutated at sites within the immunodominant epitope (NPmut), were tested after restimulation with Influenza A/PR/8/34. Virus-restimulated CTLs from immunized (both NP DNA and NP mut) mice were unable to recognize and lyse peptide NP 110-119 pulsed targets.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Epitope NP147-155 was previously defined by Townsend AR et al. Cell 1886;44:959-968.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized by vaccination using plasmid DNA encoding the full length nucleoprotein (NP DNA)of Influenza A/PR/8/34(H1N1). CTLs were maintained by culture with irradiated syngeneic splenocytes pulsed with NP147-155 peptide.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL from mice immunized with a plasmid vaccine specific for full-length Influenza A nucleoprotein (NP DNA) were tested for their ability to lyse H-2Kd-restricted targets pulsed with peptide NP147-155. CTL from mice vaccinated with NP DNA were able to lyse NP 147-155-specific, H-2Kd restricted targets. Authors conclude that full length NP DNA vaccine can induce CTL of appropriate MHC haplotype in immunologically heterologous scenario.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized by vaccination using plasmid DNA encoding the full length (or mutated version) nucleoprotein of Influenza A/PR/8/34(H1N1). CTLs from immuized mice were restimulated by culture with syngeneic splenocytes infected with Influenza A/PR/8/34 in the presence of IL-2.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL from mice immunized with a plasmid vaccine specific for a mutated form of Influenza A nucleoprotein (NPmut DNA) were tested after restimulation with Influenza A/PR/8/34. Virus-restimulated CTLs from NP mut immunized mice were unable to recognize and lyse peptide NP 147-155 pulsed targets.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized by vaccination with plasmid DNA encoding the full length nucleoprotein of Influenza A/PR/8/34(H1N1). CTLs from immunized mice were restimulated by culture with syngeneic splenocytes infected with Influenza A/PR/8/34 in the presence of IL-2.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL from mice immunized with a plasmid vaccine specific for a mutated form of Influenza A nucleoprotein (NPmut DNA) were tested after restimulation with Influenza A/PR/8/34. Virus-restimulated CTLs from NPmut DNA immunized mice were unable to recognize and lyse peptide NP 147-155 pulsed targets.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Epitope NP 218-226 was defined by scanning full length NP for consensus H-2Kd binding motifs.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized by vaccination with plasmid DNA encoding the full length nucleoprotein of Influenza A/PR/8/34(H1N1). CTLs from immunized mice were restimulated by culture with syngeneic splenocytes infected with Influenza A/PR/8/34 in the presence of IL-2.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL from mice immunized with a plasmid vaccine specific for full-length Influenza A nucleoprotein (NP DNA) were tested after restimulation with Influenza A/PR/8/34. Only virus-restimulated CTLs from NP mut immunized mice were able to recognize and lyse peptide p218-226 pulsed targets. Authors suggest that this observed change in lytic activity indicates that NP 218-226 is an immunorecessive epitope as it is immunogenic only in the absence of the immunodominant epitope, NP147-155.

P815 cells were pulsed with a mixture of 1nM NP147-155 and varying concentrations of NP218-226 peptides and then incubated with NP147-155-specific CTLs. The NP218-226 peptide was found to compete with NP147-155 for CTL recognition, suggesting that it also binds H-2Kd molecules.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Epitope NP366-374 was previously defined by Townsend AR et al. Cell 1886;44:959-968.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized by vaccination with plasmid DNA encoding the full length nucleoprotein of Influenza A/PR/8/34(H1N1). CTLs were maintained by culture for 7 days with irradiated syngeneic splenocytes pulsed with NP366-374 peptide.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL from mice immunized with a plasmid vaccine specific for full-length Influenza A nucleoprotein (NP DNA) were tested for their ability to lyse H-2Db-restricted targets pulsed with peptide NP366-374. CTL from vaccinated mice were able to lyse NP366-374-specific, H-2Db restricted targets. Authors conclude that full length NP DNA vaccine can induce CTL of appropriate MHC haplotype in immunologically heterologous scenario.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized by vaccination with plasmid DNA encoding mutated version (NPmut DNA) of Influenza A/PR/8/34(H1N1). CTLs were maintained by culture for 7 days with irradiated syngeneic splenocytes pulsed with NP366-374 peptide.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL from mice immunized with a plasmid vaccine encoding mutated form of Influenza A nucleoprotein (NPmut DNA) were tested for their ability to lyse H-2Db-restricted targets pulsed with peptide NP366-374. CTL from mice vaccinated with NPmut were able to lyse NP366-374-specific, H-2Db restricted targets. Authors conclude that point mutations to full length NP block one, but not both haplotypes tested. Mice immunized with NPmut DNA were also protected against challenged with lethal dose of Influenza A virus (A/HK/68) [Figure 7].
